siege_utilities.core.loggingÔÉÅ

siege_utilities.get_logger(name=None)[source]ÔÉÅ

Return a logger instance.

Parameters:

name (str, optional) ‚Äì Logger name. If None, returns/creates the default logger.

Returns:

Logger instance.

Return type:

logging.Logger

Examples

>>> logger = get_logger()  # Gets default logger
>>> db_logger = get_logger("database")  # Gets database logger
>>> api_logger = get_logger("api")  # Gets API logger
siege_utilities.init_logger(name='siege_utilities', log_to_file=False, log_dir='logs', level='INFO', max_bytes=5000000, backup_count=5, shared_log_file=None)[source]ÔÉÅ

Initialize and configure a named logger.

Parameters:

  • name (str) ‚Äì Logger name. Each component can have its own logger.

  • log_to_file (bool) ‚Äì If True, creates individual log file (unless shared_log_file specified).

  • log_dir (str) ‚Äì Directory for individual log files.

  • level (str|int) ‚Äì Logging level for this logger.

  • max_bytes (int) ‚Äì Max size for rotating file handler.

  • backup_count (int) ‚Äì How many backup logs to keep.

  • shared_log_file (str) ‚Äì If provided, this logger writes to shared file instead of individual file.

Returns:

Configured logger instance.

Return type:

logging.Logger

Examples

>>> # Individual loggers with separate files
>>> db_logger = init_logger("database", log_to_file=True, level="DEBUG")
>>> api_logger = init_logger("api", log_to_file=True, level="INFO")

>>> # Multiple loggers sharing one file (great for Spark!)
>>> worker1 = init_logger("worker_1", shared_log_file="spark_workers.log")
>>> worker2 = init_logger("worker_2", shared_log_file="spark_workers.log")

>>> # Use global shared configuration
>>> configure_shared_logging("/shared/logs/app.log")
>>> logger1 = init_logger("component_1")  # Automatically uses shared file
>>> logger2 = init_logger("component_2")  # Automatically uses shared file

siege_utilities.dataclass(cls=None, /, *, init=True, repr=True, eq=True, order=False, unsafe_hash=False, frozen=False, match_args=True, kw_only=False, slots=False, weakref_slot=False)[source]ÔÉÅ

Add dunder methods based on the fields defined in the class.

Examines PEP 526 __annotations__ to determine fields.

If init is true, an __init__() method is added to the class. If repr is true, a __repr__() method is added. If order is true, rich comparison dunder methods are added. If unsafe_hash is true, a __hash__() method is added. If frozen is true, fields may not be assigned to after instance creation. If match_args is true, the __match_args__ tuple is added. If kw_only is true, then by default all fields are keyword-only. If slots is true, a new class with a __slots__ attribute is returned.

siege_utilities.clean_and_reorder_bbox(df, bbox_col)[source]ÔÉÅ

Removes brackets from bounding box strings and reorders coordinates for Sedona.

Assumes input is a comma separated list in the order:

min latitude, max latitude, min longitude, max longitude

Produces an array in the order: [min_lon, min_lat, max_lon, max_lat]

siege_utilities.expr()[source]ÔÉÅ
siege_utilities.flatten_json_column_and_join_back_to_df(df, json_column, prefix='json_column_', logger=None, drop_original=True, explode_arrays=False, flatten_level='shallow', verbose=False, sample_size=5, show_samples=True)[source]ÔÉÅ

Flattens a JSON column in a Spark DataFrame, extracting fields and adding them as columns. Has fallback mechanisms for corrupt JSON data.

Parameters:

  • df (DataFrame) ‚Äì The input Spark DataFrame.

  • json_column (str) ‚Äì The name of the column containing JSON strings.

  • prefix (str, optional) ‚Äì Prefix to add to the flattened column names. Defaults to ‚Äújson_column_‚Äù.

  • logger (Optional[any], optional) ‚Äì Logger object for logging messages. Defaults to None.

  • drop_original (bool, optional) ‚Äì Whether to drop the original JSON column after flattening. Defaults to True.

  • explode_arrays (bool, optional) ‚Äì Whether to explode array columns. Defaults to False.

  • flatten_level (str, optional) ‚Äì ‚Äúshallow‚Äù or ‚Äúdeep‚Äù flattening. Defaults to ‚Äúshallow‚Äù.

  • verbose (bool, optional) ‚Äì Controls whether to log detailed messages. Defaults to False.

  • sample_size (int, optional) ‚Äì Number of samples to check. Defaults to 5.

  • show_samples (bool, optional) ‚Äì Whether to display sample data. Defaults to False.

Returns:

The DataFrame with the JSON column flattened.

Return type:

DataFrame

siege_utilities.mark_valid_geocode_data(df, lat_col_name, lon_col_name, output_col_name='is_valid')[source]ÔÉÅ

Adds a boolean flag column to the DataFrame indicating whether the geographic coordinates are valid.

A set of coordinates is considered valid if: - The latitude and longitude columns are not null. - The latitude is between -90 and 90. - The longitude is between -180 and 180.

Unlike filtering functions, this function preserves all rows in the DataFrame by simply marking each row with a True (valid) or False (invalid) value in the new output column.

Parameters:

  • df (DataFrame) ‚Äì The Spark DataFrame containing geocode data.

  • lat_col_name (str) ‚Äì The name of the latitude column.

  • lon_col_name (str) ‚Äì The name of the longitude column.

  • output_col_name (str, optional) ‚Äì The name of the output column to store the validity flag. Defaults to ‚Äúis_valid‚Äù.

Returns:

A new DataFrame with an additional column indicating geocode validity.

Return type:

DataFrame

siege_utilities.pivot_summary_table_for_bools(df, columns, spark)[source]ÔÉÅ

Generate a pivot table summary for given boolean flag columns in a DataFrame. The pivot table includes three metrics:

  • ‚ÄúCount‚Äù: Sum of rows where the flag is True.

  • ‚ÄúPercentage (%)‚Äù: Percentage relative to total records.

  • ‚ÄúTotal‚Äù: The total number of records (repeated for each column).

All numeric values are converted to float to ensure a consistent type.

Parameters:

  • df (DataFrame) ‚Äì The source Spark DataFrame.

  • columns (list) ‚Äì List of column names (assumed to be boolean flags) to summarize.

  • spark (SparkSession) ‚Äì The active Spark session.

Returns:

A Spark DataFrame representing the pivot table.

Return type:

DataFrame

siege_utilities.pivot_summary_with_metrics(df, group_col, pivot_col, spark)[source]ÔÉÅ

Generate a pivot summary for a categorical column against one or more grouping columns, including rows for ‚ÄúCount‚Äù, ‚ÄúPercentage (%)‚Äù, and ‚ÄúTotal‚Äù for each group.

Parameters:

  • df (DataFrame) ‚Äì The source Spark DataFrame.

  • group_col (str or list) ‚Äì The column name (or list of column names) used for grouping. For example, ‚Äúgeocode_granularity‚Äù or [‚Äústate‚Äù, ‚Äúregion‚Äù].

  • pivot_col (str) ‚Äì The categorical column to pivot on (e.g., ‚Äúfinal_geocode_choice‚Äù).

  • spark (SparkSession) ‚Äì The active Spark session.

Returns:

A Spark DataFrame in which each original group appears as three rows:

one for the counts, one for the percentages, and one for the total count. The non-grouping columns represent each distinct pivot column value.

Return type:

DataFrame

siege_utilities.prepare_dataframe_for_export(df, logger_func=None)[source]ÔÉÅ
Prepares a DataFrame for export (e.g., to CSV) by:

  • Converting binary columns to Base64-encoded strings.

  • Casting simple scalar fields (non-string, non-complex) to strings.

  • Dropping intermediate columns (e.g., ‚Äòparsed_json‚Äô) if present.

  • Converting complex (StructType/ArrayType) columns to JSON strings.

  • Handling null values appropriately.

Parameters:

  • df ‚Äì Spark DataFrame to prepare

  • logger_func ‚Äì Optional logging function (defaults to print)

Returns:

The transformed DataFrame with all columns as strings or JSON strings.

Helper function to create summary DataFrames with consistent string types. Prevents type merging errors by ensuring all values are strings.

Parameters:

  • data_tuples ‚Äì List of tuples with data

  • column_names ‚Äì Column names for the DataFrame

  • logger_func ‚Äì Optional logging function

Returns:

Spark DataFrame with all string columns

siege_utilities.reproject_geom_columns(df, geom_columns, source_srid, target_srid)[source]ÔÉÅ

Reprojects geometry columns using the three-argument version of ST_Transform: ST_Transform(geom, ‚Äòsource_srid‚Äô, ‚Äòtarget_srid‚Äô)

Only reprojects if the current SRID is not equal to the target.

Parameters:

  • df (DataFrame) ‚Äì Spark DataFrame containing the geometry columns.

  • geom_columns (list) ‚Äì List of column names (strings) to reproject.

  • source_srid (str) ‚Äì The source CRS (e.g. ‚ÄúEPSG:4326‚Äù).

  • target_srid (str) ‚Äì The target CRS (e.g. ‚ÄúEPSG:27700‚Äù).

Returns:

The DataFrame with each specified geometry column conditionally reprojected.

Return type:

DataFrame

siege_utilities.use_nominatim_geocoder(query_address, id=None, country_codes=None, max_retries=3)[source]ÔÉÅ

Geocode an address using Nominatim with proper rate limiting and error handling. Returns the result as a JSON string for Spark UDF compatibility.

Parameters:

  • query_address ‚Äì The address to geocode

  • id ‚Äì An identifier for tracking

  • country_codes ‚Äì Optional country code filter (default from settings)

  • max_retries ‚Äì Number of retry attempts for transient errors

Returns:

JSON string of geocoding result or None if failed
